header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 16

central_thesis: True spiritual reward and elevation are achieved not through personal enjoyment, but by dedicating all enjoyment to sharing with the community and the Creator, thereby making both happy. Any self-serving enjoyment constitutes a transgression with severe spiritual consequences, emphasizing an operative system where service to the community is directly equated with service to the Divine.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Nature of Transgression and Reward
structure_content.summary: This section outlines a core ethical and spiritual principle: personal enjoyment is permissible only to the extent that it can be shared with the public and the Creator for their happiness. Any enjoyment exceeding this degree is deemed a 'transgression,' leading to a severance of the Nefesh (Soul) from human society and subsequent reincarnation for atonement. Conversely, selfless sharing and contributing to the happiness of others and the Divine lead to spiritual reward.

The text clarifies that these actions must fundamentally be understood as 'Worshipping (or serving) the Creator,' rather than merely 'working for (or serving) the community' for its own sake. The Creator, in His wisdom, provides the community as a means for individuals to give Him pleasure, and therefore, serving one's community is recognized and accepted by the Creator as direct service to Him, providing Him contentment.

The author discusses the necessity of expanding explanations of reward and punishment in a manner accessible to the masses, acknowledging that the understanding of leaders is crucial for guiding collective action. The author asserts extensive work in refining and editing theological and mystical concepts to a deeper sense than previous works, and offers to share this refined understanding with wise individuals well-versed in their established system.

The author reveals the preparation of two distinct approaches to comprehending these teachings: one based on 'theoretical theology,' which follows conventional academic and philosophical lines; and another rooted in 'mysticism,' drawing upon insights recognized by ancient Sages over millennia. This duality allows for both rational and esoteric engagement with the material.

key_concepts.definition: Any personal enjoyment that exceeds the degree that can be shared with the public and the Creator to bring them happiness. It is not merely a moral failing but a spiritual act that severs the Nefesh from human society and necessitates reincarnation.

The consequence for transgressions involving excessive self-serving enjoyment; the Nefesh is 'completely severed from the human society' and 'would reincarnate,' implying a cycle of forced correction until atonement for the sin is achieved.

A 'payment from his maker' received by those who minimize transgression by directing their enjoyment towards sharing with the public and the Creator, aiming to make them happy. This suggests a direct causal link between altruistic action and divine recompense.

The correct underlying intent for all spiritual actions. It defines service to the community not as an end in itself, but as the divinely appointed means to directly serve and bring pleasure to the Creator. This redefines 'work' or 'service' as a devotional act.

A practical and foundational spiritual act through which the individual serves the Creator. The Creator has established the community as a vessel for individuals to manifest their desire to give Him pleasure, accepting such service as if it were rendered directly.
One of the two primary ways presented by the author for understanding the teachings, described as following conventional intellectual and philosophical frameworks common in present-day discourse.

The second primary way of understanding the teachings, based on profound insights and recognition of 'things which have been recognized by the Wise of yore in the past few thousand years,' indicating an esoteric, experiential, and tradition-based approach.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a method of conscious redirection of personal desire and enjoyment. Instead of self-gratification, the practitioner must actively channel any pleasure or benefit gained towards 'sharing to the public and to the Creator.' This transforms personal experience into an act of divine service. The core mechanic is the spiritual calculus of 'transgression' and 'reward' based on this redirection of intent and action. Service to the community ('being useful to them') is the primary operative means to actualize 'Worshipping (or serving) the Creator,' which is explicitly stated to be accepted by the Creator as if direct. This system aims to purify the Nefesh, prevent negative reincarnation, and achieve spiritual elevation through altruistic intent embedded in daily life.
tools: The understanding and application of the 'degree' of enjoyment permitted (only that which can be shared).
The internal 'intention' to serve the Creator through community service.
The knowledge of 'reward and punishment' as a motivating and guiding principle.
The refined 'theology and mysticism' as taught by the author, providing conceptual frameworks for practice.
rituals: Conscious redirection of all enjoyment towards sharing with the public and the Creator.
Engaging in acts of service and being useful to one's community as a direct form of worship.
Cultivating an inner intent to please the Creator through all actions, especially those benefiting others.

relevant_quotes.text: Therefore, whoever does this transgression less receives his reward as a payment from his maker; in such a manner that one should not enjoy anything in this world only to the degree that he would share to the public and to the Creator, in order to make the Creator and the people happy.

And any drop of enjoyment exceeding this degree is a transgression and the Nefesh (Soul) should be completely severed from the human society and would reincarnate, and would be put to work against his will (all this unless he atones for that sin).
And of course these things have to be in the form of 'Worshipping (or serving) the Creator' and not 'working for (or serving) the community'.

But because the Creator has provided us with ways to give Him pleasure, He has prepared a community for each individual. And it is a great rule that one should serve one's community and be useful to them. And the Creator accepts this service and this contentment, as if it came directly to Him; in the same degree of benefit and satisfaction received by those who live in His world

And for this I have prepared two ways: one, which follows theoretical theology, as is common up to the present in all matters; and the second, according to the mysticism, based on things which have been recognized by the Wise of yore in the past few thousand years.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text articulates a fundamental operative principle within Rav Ashlag's Kabbalistic system: the spiritual imperative of altruism and the re-channeling of egoic desire. It is highly relevant to understanding the ethical and practical dimensions of Jewish mysticism, particularly how divine service is instantiated through social engagement. It frames communal action not as mere philanthropy, but as a direct spiritual practice that impacts one's soul and relationship with the Creator, linking mundane acts to profound esoteric consequences like reincarnation. This perspective is vital for practitioners seeking to integrate spiritual work with daily life and understand the mechanics of cosmic justice within the Ashlag lineage.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes advanced students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those within the Rav Ashlag tradition, or seekers already familiar with esoteric Jewish thought. The author specifically mentions sending a 'group of wise people who are well versed with your system' to examine his work, indicating a readership capable of deep engagement with complex theological and mystical frameworks. However, the mention of expanding explanations 'to the degree that fits the masses' also suggests an intent for broader dissemination, albeit likely through interpretive layers designed by knowledgeable leaders.
